title: How to Check a Penis for Signs of Sexual Infection

steps.title: Know that the symptoms of gonorrhea and chlamydia may not be obvious.
steps.content: Know that the symptoms of gonorrhea and chlamydia may not be obvious. You or your partner may have all, some, or none of these symptoms. Gonorrhea and chlamydia are bacterial infections. Symptoms gonorrhea typically arise within 10 days after exposure; symptoms of chlamydia typically arise one to three weeks after exposure. [1] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Gonorrhea and chlamydia can both infect the genital tract, eyes, mouth, pharynx, and anus. [2] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Check your penis for signs of discharge.
steps.content: Check your penis for signs of discharge. If you have chlamydia or gonorrhea, you may notice a lot of discharge coming from your urethra. [3] X Expert Source Robert Dhir, MD Board Certified Urologist & Urological Surgeon Expert Interview. 12 October 2020. That discharge might be yellow, green, thick, bloody, or cloudy. [4] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source [5] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source Discharge from the penis is not a normal occurrence, but its presence does not necessarily mean you have an STI. The only way to find out for sure is to visit a healthcare provider and be tested.

steps.title: Notice if you have pain or a burning sensation while urinating.
steps.content: Notice if you have pain or a burning sensation while urinating. Infection of the urethra by gonorrhea bacteria can cause inflammation of the urethra. [6] X Research source This, in turn, can cause pain or a burning sensation.

steps.title: Palpate (feel) your testicles.
steps.content: Palpate (feel) your testicles. If they are tender, painful, or swollen, seek medical attention. This can be a symptom of gonorrhea, chlamydia, or another disease. [7] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source [8] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source

steps.title: Check for symptoms of anal gonorrhea or anal chlamydia infection.
steps.content: Check for symptoms of anal gonorrhea or anal chlamydia infection. These include itching of the anus, pain when having a bowel movement, anal soreness, anal bleeding, swollen prostate, and anal discharge. [9] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source [10] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source

steps.title: Have your partner check themselves for symptoms.
steps.content: Have your partner check themselves for symptoms. If your partner has symptoms of gonorrhea or chlamydia (even if you do not show symptoms), you should both seek medical treatment. If your partner has a penis, follow the same checks as listed above. If your partner has a vagina, follow the guidance listed below: Check for increased vaginal discharge, or discharge that is not a typical color, odor, consistency, or appearance. This can be a symptom of gonorrhea or chlamydia infection. [11] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source [12] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source Check for pain or burning when urinating. This can be a sign of gonorrhea or chlamydia infection. [13] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source [14] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source Women can also get anal gonorrhea or anal chlamydia. The symptoms include itching of the anus, pain when having a bowel movement, anal soreness, anal bleeding, and anal discharge. [15] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source [16] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source Vaginal bleeding between periods can also be indicative of gonorrhea infection. [17] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source

steps.title: Seek medical care if you have any of the symptoms mentioned.
steps.content: Seek medical care if you have any of the symptoms mentioned. Gonorrhea and chlamydia can cause permanent damage to your body if left untreated.

steps.title: Check your genitals, mouth, and anus for primary syphilis sores.
steps.content: Check your genitals, mouth, and anus for primary syphilis sores. (Have your partner check themselves as well.) The sores often appear as open, wet ulcers, or painless sores. [18] X Research source These sores, caused by infection with syphilis bacteria, typically appear between 10 days and three months after exposure. [19] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source They appear on the region of the body infected (such as the penis, vagina, tongue, lips, anus) and heal up, though the disease remains in the body. Secondary syphilis can reappear later on. [20] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source

steps.title: Evaluate yourself for signs of secondary syphilis.
steps.content: Evaluate yourself for signs of secondary syphilis. These symptoms begin three to six weeks after the disappearance of the primary syphilis sore and include: [21] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Rash with ¾ inch red or brownish sores — This is the most classical sign of secondary syphilis. The rash is characterized as a rash (a flat, red area covered with bumps) over the trunk and extremities that includes the palms and soles of the hands and feet Fever Headache Sore throat Anorexia Muscle pain Weight loss Alopecia Gastrointestinal Findings Musculoskeletal Problems Neurological and Ocular Findings Swollen lymph nodes General feeling of malaise

steps.title: Be aware that syphilis may, at any point in the course of the infection, spread to the nervous system.
steps.content: Be aware that syphilis may, at any point in the course of the infection, spread to the nervous system. This is dangerous and can cause neurological symptoms including uncoordinated movement and changes in behavior. In addition, secondary syphilis can lead to tertiary syphilis, which may spread to organs including and cause life-threatening complications. Neurosyphilis is difficult to diagnose and usually spinal fluid must be tested to confirm.

steps.title: Seek medical care if you have any of the symptoms listed above or suspect you may have syphilis.
steps.content: Seek medical care if you have any of the symptoms listed above or suspect you may have syphilis. This is a dangerous disease that can cause permanent damage and even death if left untreated. Talk to your doctor immediately and get tested.

steps.title: Look for red, open sores; blisters; or small, red bumps in the genital or anal areas.
steps.content: Look for red, open sores; blisters; or small, red bumps in the genital or anal areas. [22] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Sores can appear on the penis, scrotum, and even inside the urethra. Genital herpes is a viral infection caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV). This classically causes a painful sore on the penis or vagina. Though outbreaks of genital herpes can be managed with medication, once a person is infected, they will always carry the virus in their body.

steps.title: Note any pain or itching in the genital region, thighs, buttocks, or anus.
steps.content: Note any pain or itching in the genital region, thighs, buttocks, or anus. Itching is typically the first symptoms of a herpes infection. Herpes sores are also painful, which can help you differentiate herpes from other conditions. [23] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Be aware of discomfort when urinating.
steps.content: Be aware of discomfort when urinating. Herpes sores can occur inside the urethra, making urination painful. [24] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Know that there are many types of HPV.
steps.content: Know that there are many types of HPV. The kinds that cause cancer are not the same kinds that cause genital warts. [25] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source There is also no way to test for the presence of HPV in men.

steps.title: Examine your penis for small flesh-colored or gray-colored wart-like lesions.
steps.content: Examine your penis for small flesh-colored or gray-colored wart-like lesions. Individual genital warts are often small — less than 1 millimeter in diameter; however, they may multiply and several can grow in close proximity to each other. [26] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source This can cause the warts to look like cauliflower. [27] X Expert Source Robert Dhir, MD Board Certified Urologist & Urological Surgeon Expert Interview. 12 October 2020. The warts can be located in and around the genitals, anus, and in the mouth and the back of the throat.

steps.title: Note any bleeding after sexual intercourse.
steps.content: Note any bleeding after sexual intercourse. [28] X Research source This can be a sign of genital warts or another condition.

steps.title: Be aware of itching or pain in the genital region, on the buttocks, or in the mouth.
steps.content: Be aware of itching or pain in the genital region, on the buttocks, or in the mouth. These signs can point to genital warts or another STI.

steps.title: Understand that there are typically no symptoms from infection by the types of HPV that can cause cancer in men and in women.
steps.content: Understand that there are typically no symptoms from infection by the types of HPV that can cause cancer in men and in women. In men, these types of HPV can cause penile, anal, or oropharyngeal cancer. [29] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source In women, these types of HSV can cause cervical, anal, or oropharyngeal cancer. [30] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source There are vaccines that can prevent infection with some types of HPV that cause cancer or genital warts. [31] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source Men between the ages of nine and 26 are approved to receive HPV vaccines Gardasil and Gardasil. [32] X Research source

steps.title: Seek medical care if you have any of the symptoms listed above.
steps.content: Seek medical care if you have any of the symptoms listed above. Your healthcare provider can prescribe medications to treat genital warts, and can advise you about cancer risk if you have a cancer-causing type of HPV.

steps.title: Make sure that you and your partner are following the recommended screening guidelines for STIs.
steps.content: Make sure that you and your partner are following the recommended screening guidelines for STIs. If your partner is a woman, there are certain tests she should get on a regular basis. If your partner is a man, he should be screened for certain STIs. [33] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source These tests can tell you if you or your partner have an STI, allowing you to take proper precautions and to seek treatment. Some STDs, including HIV, Hepatitis B, and Hepatitis C usually do not present with symptoms early on, so they must be detected on a blood test. [34] X Expert Source Robert Dhir, MD Board Certified Urologist & Urological Surgeon Expert Interview. 12 October 2020. These guidelines are just that — a guide. You should discuss all testing and risk factors with your healthcare provider, and they will help you adjust screening accordingly. Make sure your partner is also tested and treated accordingly.

steps.title: Get tested for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) at least once in your life between 13 – 64 years of age.
steps.content: Get tested for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) at least once in your life between 13 – 64 years of age. Men who have sex with men should be tested at least yearly, if not more frequently. [35] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source

steps.title: Get tested for gonorrhea and chlamydia yearly if you are under 25 years old, or if you have new or multiple sex partners.
steps.content: Get tested for gonorrhea and chlamydia yearly if you are under 25 years old, or if you have new or multiple sex partners. [36] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source Having multiple sex partners puts you at an increased risk for STIs.

steps.title: Get tested for syphilis, gonorrhea, and chlamydia yearly if you are a man who has sex of any kind with other men.
steps.content: Get tested for syphilis, gonorrhea, and chlamydia yearly if you are a man who has sex of any kind with other men. [37] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source Men who have multiple and/or anonymous partners should be tested more frequently. [38] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source
